reviewText: I would absolutely give this movie more stars if I could! This movie came out in select theaters in January. We had the intention to go see it, but it disappeared as quickly as it appeared. We waited on pins and needles for it to come out so we could buy it. It came out yesterday but it was too late for us to watch, so we watched it tonight. We were not disappointed! We were interested in this movie because my 16 year old son has been on a high school robotics team in Denver, CO for 2 years now. Last year the team came in 2nd in State, making us ineligible to compete in the World Championship. This school year, we not only won nearly every competition, but we took State, and made it to the World Championship this year! The team won their division of 90 teams and then went on to compete against the other 4 division winners for the top prize. Our Fuse team took 3rd in the World! We knew what these kids in this movie have been through, we have been the underdogs, and we came out nearly on top. We have felt the defeat, but we have felt the exhilaration too!

This is a feel-good story based on actual events.  Geoorge Lopez has a more serious role in this movie, and Jamie Lee Curtis and Marissa Tomei round this out.  The four students profiled are unknowns and that is what makes this movie so enjoyable.  Their characters are based on real students who thought they stood no chance of succeeding despite their talents.

Lopez plays a man needing a job.  He takes on a substitute teaching job for a few months.  Several boys relate to him and when one student wants to join the robotics club and enter in a competition, that's when the plot truly begins.  But each kid has personal challenges to overcome, and we also learn that the teacher does, too.  Against all odds, this ends in a happy end for the team and at the end, during the credits, we learn what happened to the real kids this story is based on.

This movie is suitable for classroom viewing.  There is some violence and a few cuss words but they are realistic for the scenes.

Great movie. People complaining that it has a "liberal agenda" are generally not happy when confronted with facts that don't meet their personal view of the world. Nonetheless, this movie is based on fact, and yes, the characters are portraying real life kids who grew up in the States, and wanted to better themselves and lead productive lives. One actually served in the Middle East and received his citizenship after putting his life on the line for our country. These kids proved that even though they are minorities, even though they were here illegally, they had something positive to offer our country in the form of intelligence and diligence. To beat top engineering schools in a national competition on a dime is no small feat, and their story is inspirational. Alas, we value dumb/self righteous "American born" people who sit on their butts and complain about their jobs being taken away by minorities more than we do what made America great in the first place: Gumption and drive, and the understanding that education leads to a better quality of life for all. Sad ending for some of these young men. Had they been from Europe here illegally, they might have had better luck, but alas, they had dark skin.

I was pleasantly surprised by Spare Parts.  I guess that's because I hadn't heard about the movie.  The acting was quite good and the production quality was excellent.  As always, with a "based on a true story" movie, I wonder how many of the details were fabricated.  But, the story was inspirational and it lacked nothing that you'd expect in a first rate movie with actual plot and character development.  The subplots were very good and carried some excellent messages.  It was a very nice break from CGI and endless battle scenes.  Having said all of that, I think I'd be remiss if I didn't address what appears to be the underlying message in this movie.  It is one that can take on the "us and them" flavor of so many controversial issues.  As a country, do we want to throw out the rules to allow undocumented people in?  I do not know the true character of the individuals in the movie.  They are portrayed as flawed, but justifiably so.  No attempt is made to cover some of the unacceptable behaviors but we are expected to be sympathetic.  This is a tough one for me because I believe in being held accountable for one's actions.  I had a very flawed upbringing.  Does that excuse me from following a reasonable set of rules?  No.  Do I sometimes fail?  Yes.  Should the rules then be set aside to accommodate my failures?  No.  I don't want to over simplify a very complex issue.  But, a society needs to have some basic rules.  If the rules regarding people entering our country are unfair or unreasonable, fix them.  Don't simply ignore them then enable those who break them.  I am only second generation born in this country.  My grandparents came through Ellis Island, legally and went through the process of becoming citizens.  Was that unfair?  They didn't think so.

I appreciate the story of scrappy young men wanting to compete in an underwater robotics competition (full disclosure: I have been affiliated with the MATE Competition - the one featured, but not named in the film - for six years) but the writers missed the mark on the technical aspects and completely cheapened the hard work and steep learning curve for every student who enters this competition for weak laughs.

The first cringe-worthy comment was made during the sales pitch by the students - "we can use these Styrofoam blocks as ballast" (Yeah, good luck with that). Which was quickly followed on by some mysterious electrical work that blows up leaving a student with char-marks around his safety glasses.

That's when I turned it off.  The acting might have eventually been brilliant.  The story of the Carl Hayden team is inspirational - but it was reduced to trite gags and bad science.  I couldn't stomach it and shut it down.

The rating it two stars - only because one star seems too harsh for the REAL people in this story.  Take the writers out to the pasture - this could have been so much more.

Also, (perhaps?) a love interest in Marisa Tomei, dodging ICE's illegal immigrant hunters, conflicts in mixed families (citizen children mixed with illegal immigrant children), and how easy it is to judge other's harsh family life until you know all the problems they face.

The book is always better than the movie.  Don't get me wrong, I loved the movie.  But then I had to read the book to know the real life details.  While the movie ends on an "up" note, real life has both ups and downs.  Indeed, there is a lot more to the story of these young men.  I think it should be required for everyone in the U.S. to read this book and/or something like it.  There is such a negative outlook on immigrants, and particularly those who came to the U.S. illegally, but what about kids?  They are brought here and it's the only life they know.  Should they be expected to give up their life and move to a country that is strange to them when they turn 18?  And, the portrayal of an immigrant is often negative, yet here is a group of young men who weren't out getting into trouble.  They were sharpening their minds and becoming very promising engineers who could certainly contribute to our country.  When I read this I can't help but think what a shame it is that public policy is so rigid and so negative that we, as a country, are missing out on great talent like these kids.  And, these kids may miss out on a bright future for which they worked hard.  It just doesn't seem like the American Dream.  Read the story; it will definitely make you think, and hopefully, act.

When I saw information on this movie online, I thought it sounded familiar -- I had read an article in Reader's Digest that sounded a lot like the premise of this movie.  Intrigued, I decided to check out the movie for myself.  I'm mostly familiar with George Lopez as a comedic actor, and I could only hope that his presence wouldn't detract from the more serious premise of the movie.  And I hoped to get a little more insight into the story of four underprivileged high school students who managed to not only compete among elite college students, but achieve greatness.

The movie is simply... okay.  I like a good underdog story, but at the same time this movie feels too much like a bog-standard "teacher reforms tough-luck students" story, one we've seen countless times before.

George Lopez plays Fredi Cameron, an engineer who's taking on a temporary job as a substitute teacher at Carl Hayden High School in Arizona.  The principal, played by Jamie Lee Curtis, has grim expectations for all Cameron's students, saying that many of them are undocumented and all are simply out to cause trouble.  But Cameron has more faith in his students, and when the robotics club he founds on a whim attracts four Hispanic students (one an illegal alien who harbors dreams of serving in the military), he decides they're going to build their own robot... and enter it into a prestigious robotics competition.  The four students must band together, scrape together funds and materials for building their robot, and overcome parental strife and run-ins with the law to make it to the competition, and even then they'll be competing against some of the top colleges in the nation...

I loved the original story, but somehow seeing it in film form weakens and dilutes it.  The filmmakers have taken the original story and turned it into a typical "teacher comes to tough high school and does good" story, in the same vein as "Stand and Deliver," "Lean On Me," and countless other films.  And some parts of the film make me wonder if they weren't tacked on or exaggerated in order to make for more dramatic moments or to further mold the original story to fit the "teacher saves students" plot.  I understand that this is Hollywood and that they will inevitably alter details of true stories to make for a more watchable film, but it's still irksome when it happens.

The acting in this film is strong, however, and mostly saves it from being simply mediocre.  George Lopez tones down his funny-man act and turns in a good dramatic performance -- still friendly, but keeping a rein on the goofy antics.  Jamie Lee Curtis shows grit and toughness as the school's cynical principal, but also has a good heart beneath.  And the actors playing the four students show various sides to the audience -- tough, funny, smart, cynical -- but these sides never clash and make for a good group dynamic among them.  Most other roles are fairly flat and unmemorable, with the rest of the cast seeming to be there simply to "fill in the blanks," as it were.

While the movie makes me curious to learn more about the true story behind it, it feels pretty average and bog-standard to me.  If you've seen "Stand and Deliver" or "Lean On Me," you already have a good idea how this movie's going to go, and it holds little in the way of surprises.  Still, it's worth a watch, mostly for the acting and the group dynamic amongst the students.  Probably best for ages 12 and up due to language and some frightening moments.
